content:
No, none of the examples I mentioned are close to the amount of power required for a worm to cut through stone, as cutting through stone would require an incredibly high amount of force and energy relative to the size of the worm.

The force required to cut through stone would depend on a variety of factors, including the hardness of the stone, the thickness of the cut, and the speed of the cutting action. However, it is likely that cutting through stone would require a force on the order of hundreds or thousands of newtons, which is several orders of magnitude greater than the forces generated by the animals I mentioned.

Additionally, cutting through stone would likely require a sustained effort over a relatively long period of time, which would be challenging for an animal to maintain. While there are some examples of animals that are capable of sustained, powerful movements over extended periods of time (such as migratory birds or long-distance runners), the amount of force required to cut through stone would be much greater than what is typically observed in the animal kingdom.
